data.text:
Paul Dupuis is not a name that rings a bell to many people of my generation. However, if I talk about him with my grandparents or older people, they‚Äôll remember him as this handsome man with a very deep voice who was ‚Äúgreat in Les Belles Histories des Pays d‚Äôen Haut‚Äú. He was one of those French-Canadian actors that had his notoriety, but who is, unfortunately, a bit forgotten nowadays. On my side, if I hadn‚Äôt seen Madness of the Heart (Charles Bennett, 1949), I probably wouldn‚Äôt have come across him. When I watched the British film for the first time, this handsome young man, who was cast as Margaret Lockwood‚Äôs love interest, picked my curiosity. So, I checked what was his name: Paul Dupuis. Hum, that‚Äôs sounded French! It was even better, he was a Quebecois. Last year, in my class on Quebec cinema, I decided to do my final essay on films of the 40‚Äôs and the 50‚Äôs, but, to tell you the truth, that was mainly an excuse to see more of Paul Dupuis‚Äôs films. I don‚Äôt regret it, because I saw some interesting stuff, movies that, just like Paul, are not remembered very well today.

I‚Äôm really not an expert on Paul Dupuis and I‚Äôve seen only three of his films (see Note 1), but I‚Äôve chosen to write about him because I think he deserves more recognition. And if, like me, you like to discover new actors, well, there you go. I, however, have a sort of obsession with him and sometimes I can spend hours looking for articles and videos about him on the web. Quite a stimulating activity. It‚Äôs mostly through this research that I discovered myself a real fascination for the man. Paul Dupuis was one of a kind, and he was much more than a ‚Äúsimple‚Äù movie star.

With the help of all my readings, I created this mini biography that I hope you‚Äôll find complete and informative.

Who Was Paul Dupuis?

Birthday and college years

Paul Dupuis was born in Montreal on August 11, 1916 (or 1913 according to some sources). He was the son of Carmel Girouard and Pierre-Louis Dupuis, a juvenile court judge. From 1933 to 1934 he did classical studies at Coll√®ge de l‚ÄôAssomption. Paul Dupuis‚Äôs love for acting started when he attended Coll√®ge St-Laurent and was part of the amateur theatre group ‚ÄúLes Compagnons de St-Laurent‚Äù (or simply ‚ÄúLes Compagnons‚Äù) created by Father Legault, to whom he owned his love for the theatre. In an article from La Voix de Shawinigan, Gabriel Langlais describes Paul Dupuis as ‚ÄúFather Legault‚Äôs spiritual son‚Äù. Later, after Paul became an established movie and stage actor, he eventually became an assistant director, actor, professor, and director at Les Compagnons, at the request of Father Legault. His passage at Les Compagnons is well remembered for his successful performance in Shakespeare‚Äôs Henry IV as the leading role, in 1951.

The journalist

It‚Äôs important to know that, despite his talent for acting, it was a bit by accident that he became an actor. Yes, he spent glorious times performing with Les Compagnons, but Paul first worked (briefly) as a newspaper cartoonist. He also worked as an announcer and director at Radio-Canada and joined CBC in 1937 and was sent, not long after, in London, as a war correspondent. Meanwhile, he married Jacqueline-Th√©r√®se Godin (daughter of Joseph-Eug√®ne Godin et Hortense Mongenais) at St-L√©on-de-Westmount church in 1939. They had two children, Pierre-Louis and Marie. In 1945, Paul, who then was a journalist, not an actor yet, made an important war reportage entitled Mort du Soldat Bourdage au Front in which he talked about the death of Private Bourdage and made a glorious portrait of him. However, the soldier was not really dead! His trace was lost after an explosion and he was declared dead, but a bit too early. Fortunately, this allowed Bourdage to see Dupuis‚Äôs wonderful tribute to him.

The rise of an actor

Paul Dupuis‚Äôs first on-screen role (or should I say ‚Äúappearance) was in Yellow Canary, a 1943‚Äôs British spy movie by Herbert Wilcox. He, however, was uncredited. Paul Dupuis first important role was in 1945‚Äôs Johnny Frenchman, a film about a Breton fisherman directed by Charles Frend and also starring Patricia Roc, Paul Walls and Fran√ßoise Rosay. It‚Äôs a screen-test arranged by his friend Gerry Wilmott (who also worked at Radio-Canada) who led him to obtain an important role in the film. Paul then became a revelation, both in Europe and in his native country, Canada, where the film was first screened at Imperial Theatre in Montreal during Spring 1946. Johnny Frenchman was praised for its quality. An article from Independent Exhibitors Film Bulletin said that it had ‚Äúa realism impossible to duplicate in Hollywood-made product.‚Äù The same journalist wrote that he and his co-star Patricia Roc were ‚Äúnatural and appealing as the British-French romantic pair.‚Äù Journalist Marc Thibeault also described him as a future big star of British cinema in his article ‚ÄúJohnny Frenchman‚Äù, avec Paul Dupuis, une agr√©able surprise. Due to his success in the film, Paul Dupuis signed a long time contract with J. Arthur Rank in the 40s.

From 1945 to 1951, he starred in about 15 films in England, including The White Unicorn (Bernard Knowles, 1947), Sleeping Car to Trieste (John Paddy Carstairs, 1948), Passport to Pimlico (Henry Cornelius, 1949), Madness of the Heart and The Reluctant Widow (Bernard Knowles, 1950). For many of these roles, only good things were said about Paul Dupuis:

For their performance in the comedy-thriller Sleeping Car to Trieste, Paul Dupuis and his co-stars Derrick de Marney and Jean Kent were said to be ‚Äúprominent in the action‚Äù in a Showmen‚Äôs Trade Review article of April 1949. Another article from the same magazine qualified his performance in Passport to Pimlico (June 1949) of ‚Äúconvincing‚Äù. Moreover, a July 1949‚Äôs article praised Paul Dupuis‚Äô performance in Madness of the Heart (his second film alongside Margaret Lockwood, the first one being The White Unicorn) and said about it:‚ÄùPaul Dupuis proves his ability with a sincere, clear-cut characterization as the French husband.‚Äù The film has its faults, but, like many Margaret Lockwood‚Äôs films from the 40‚Äôs, it was a commercial success. There is no doubt on the convincing performances of the actors: Paul the French gentleman, Margaret Lockwood, his blind wife, and Kathleen Byron as the mean and jealous woman. The film was directed by Charles Bennett, better-remembered for his collaborations with Alfred Hitchcock as a screenwriter (Blackmail, The Man Who Knew Too Much (1934), The 39 Steps, Sabotage, Secret Agent, Young & Innocent, Foreign Correspondent and Saboteur).

Paul‚Äôs career in Europe was not only spent in England but also in France where he starred in L‚ÄôInconnue de Montr√©al (Jean Devaivre, 1950), Les P√©p√©s font la loi (Raoul Andr√©, 1955), Passion de femmes (Hans Herwig, 1955), etc.

Despite his success in Europe in the 40‚Äôs and 50‚Äôs, and his international reputation, Paul‚Äôs heart really belonged to Canada, and I believe the importance of his career, his unique persona was really created in his native country. In a June 1951‚Äôs article for Photo Journal, Paul Dupuis was quoted saying ‚ÄúIl faut quitter le Canada pour l‚Äôappr√©cier. Je n‚Äôai jamais √©t√© un immigr√©. Les ann√©es pass√©es loin de mon pays on √©t√© pour moi des ann√©es d‚Äôexil, malgr√© le succ√®s qu‚Äôon s‚Äôest plu √† me reconna√Ætre en Europe. (You have to quit Canada to appreciate it. I never was an immigrant. The years spent far from my country were, for me years, an exile, despite the success I had in Europe).‚Äù This was his answer to the question ‚ÄúWhy are you coming back?‚Äù (to Canada). Interestingly enough, after the shooting of Madness of the Heart, Paul had a desire to go back to Canada with a Norwegian Cargo (as the road was more adventurous), but he had to cancel as the boat reservations were already all booked and he was requested to star in the film The Romantic Age (Edmond T. Gr√©ville, 1949).

Paul‚Äôs first film made in Quebec was La Forteresse, a 1946‚Äôs film directed by F√©dor Ozep in which he plays the role of an author-compositor suspected of murder. His co-stars were Nicole Germain, Jacques Auger et Henri Letondal. The outdoor scenes were shot in Quebec City and Montmorency Falls. That‚Äôs the second Paul Dupuis‚Äô film I saw and he didn‚Äôt fail to impress me.

In Canada, Paul was also seen in √âtienne Br√ªl√©, Gibier de Potence (Melburn E. Turner, 1952), Ti-Coq, or Les Belles Histoires des Pays d‚Äôen Haut on television. Actually, if you mentioned Paul Dupuis to a Quebecois, it‚Äôs more likely Tit-Coq (Ren√© Delacroix, 1953) and the series Les Belles Histoires, which should ring a bell. These are the productions he is most well-remembered for here. He grabbed the attention of writer Claude-Henri Grignon, author of Un homme et son p√©ch√©, and that‚Äôs how he obtained the role of Arthur Buies in the radio version of the novel as well as the television adaptation (entitled Les Belles Histoires des Pays d‚Äôen Haut). I have to be honest, I never saw Paul in Les Belles histories, but I‚Äôve heard only good things about it. (See Note 2) Paul Dupuis himself liked the character and found him to be quite appealing. As for Tit-Coq, a screen adaptation of Gratien G√©linas‚Äôs play, his role is small, but appreciable and convincing. What I like about it is that he inspires wisdom.

The theatre man

‚Äù Actually, I would like to appear in the theatre, but I would have to be sure that the play and the part are just right for me, otherwise I think such an experiment would do me harm than good.‚Äù (Paul Dupuis, interviewed by Anthony Firth for Picturegoer, 1949)

We all remember that Paul‚Äôs interest in acting started while he was an actor for Les Compagnons de St-Laurent. His onstage career, however, didn‚Äôt stop there. While he was in England, he played in West-End London‚Äôs theatres, but, once again, his artistic heart truly belonged to Canada. There, we saw him on stage in Ten Little Indians in 1953 (presented by the Canadian Players), Henri IV (as mentionned earlier), or in Claudel-Honegger‚Äôs Jeanne d‚ÄôArc au B√ªcher in the role of Brother Dominic. The play was staged by Jan Doat (stage director at l‚Äôop√©ra de Paris) and bandmaster Wilfrid Pelletier. The premiere took place at the Palais du Commerce in July 1952 and opened the Festival 1953. Paul was chosen by la Soci√©t√© des Festivals de Montr√©al to star in the play, alongside Claude Nollier.

Radio and television

In the 60‚Äôs, Paul Dupuis forged an important radio and television career in Canada, putting his cinematic career a bit aside. On the television, he was the animator of Voix de Femmes, a feminine magazine where Mme Fran√ßoise Gaudet-Smet was revealing to women the secrets to be a good housekeeper and where Th√©r√®se Casgrain was defending women‚Äôs legal rights. He was also seen on the cinematographic television show: Billet de faveur. He often made important reportages for Radio-Canada, both on radio and television. I remember my uncle mentioning a coffee commercial with Paul Dupuis. I tried to find more information about it, but without success.

Apart from being recognized for his acting talent, his charm and his beauty, it seems that Paul Dupuis also had a magical speaking voice, which could surely assure him a successful radio career. Journalist Fernand C√¥t√© said of Paul Dupuis that he was excellent at reading texts and giving them all their ‚Äúflavour and texture‚Äù and that he had a ‚Äúconvincing voice tone‚Äù. His voice was also said to be ‚Äúamused, malicious and tragic‚Äù. On the radio, Paul Dupuis played the role of Julien B√©dard in Jeunesse Dor√©, was the narrator of Une demie heure avec.. directed by Madeleine G√©r√¥me, reader for the special program of l‚ÄôOrganisation des mesures d‚Äôurgence, narrator for the show about the arctic Au Pays du Long Sommeil by Andr√© Morin (although I‚Äôm not sure if this was a television or a radio show‚Ä¶), animator for Billet de Faveur, etc.

Mysterious Death

Despite his success on the radio and television in the 60‚Äôs, Paul Dupuis mysteriously put an end to his career in 1970. In 1976, he was found dead at the Nymark hotel in St-Sauveur, where he lived. He was buried at the C√¥te-des-Neiges Cemetery. Now, I‚Äôm a bit confused by the subject since, an article from The Montreal Gazette says that he died of natural causes, while Claude Jasmin, writer and once Paul Dupuis‚Äôs neighbourg, implicitly mentions a suicide in his blogging article ‚Äù Mort √† St-Sauveur‚Äù. The writer mentions Paul‚Äôs difficult personality (which puy him on the ‚Äúblacklist‚Äù), alcohol problems, and his career downfall (which could indeed eventually lead to a suicide). Is it all true? Just like the man, I think this will remain a mystery and for the moment the sources on the subject are a bit limited. However, Paul Dupuis was much more than that, and he will always be remembered for the goods he brought to journalism, cinema, radio and television.

The personality

Yes, because Paul Dupuis was much more than a simple actor, he was a real personality, one of a kind. Interestingly enough, when he was criticized about his look, his answer on the subject was a bit similar to Ingrid Bergman‚Äôs one: while being interviewed by Anthony Firth for Picturegoer in 1949, he said to the journalist ‚ÄúAt the beginning of my career, I have been told that my nose is not right to which I only answer: so what? I do not consider myself a glamour boy of the screen, and if my nose can stop me from becoming a good actor then I might as well look for another profession.‚Äù Well, take me like I am or don‚Äôt take me at all! That‚Äôs the spirit. Paul loved his acting profession, and it was much more about talent than physical look for him. However, don‚Äôt get me wrong, he was often known as ‚Äúthe handsome Paul Dupuis‚Äù.

Paul had a unique personality. Known as a very private man, he inspired both fear and respect, was a man of fine tastes, an independent, he was very polite, etc. Paul didn‚Äôt like to talk about himself, but he loved talking about his passions and interests. He appreciated music and his tastes were various: while he enjoyed Gregorian chants or Mozart, he also found a real revelation in blues and rock and roll, especially with Elvis Presley‚Äôs music. Paul also loved to read, especially authors of the 18e century. He loved nature, car rides (for him, to drive from St-Sauveur to Montreal and vice versa every day was not a problem), animals (especially horses and dogs), etc. His other hobbies were squash, singing, but what he liked to most was painting, as it is written in Anthony Firth‚Äôs article. Paul also was an eccentric of his own kind. For example, as it is revealed by Fernand C√¥t√©, if he has to go to the Place des Arts (an important concert hall in Montreal) after a day of horse riding, he would go wearing his horse riding‚Äôs outfit! Fernando C√¥t√© also said of Paul Dupuis that, despite some of his life challenges, he chose meditation and reflection instead of wickedness and aggressively. Paul was a wise and thoughtful man.

As you can see, it is quite surprising that Paul Dupuis is a bit forgotten today, despite his success while he was alive. If I‚Äôve seen only three of his films: Madness of the Heart, La Forteresse, and Ti-Coq, it‚Äôs really by reading all these articles about him that I became a fan. I mean, he was such a brilliant man!

I recently bought this autograph on eBay!

And also this old magazine with Paul on the front page.

I hope I managed to give you an accurate life portrait of this magnificent French-Canadian man. It required a lot of research, which I had, fortunately, mostly done before I even considered writing this article. If you wish to watch his films, why don‚Äôt you do like me and start with Madness of the Heart?

I also invite you to check some of these Radio-Canada‚Äôs appearances and reportages from Paul Dupuis. It‚Äôs in French, but I think it‚Äôs worthy just to hear his voice. üôÇ
